reviewText: Did you know the script for Dreamer - Inspired by a True Story was bouncing around Hollywood before Seabiscuit was ever penned as a screenplay?Did you know that the wisdom of Hollywood after the huge success of Seabiscuit was to cast Dreamer aside?And just like a claimer who springboards from the mid-level tracks to placing in graded stakes, Dreamer became a winner even with the odds against it reaching the starting line.The star of the movie is Dakota Fanning, who portrays the daughter of a struggling family of a horse trainer who has a twin burden; living up to the standard in the industry set by his father-in-law and trying to compete in a sport that has little room left for a small operation. Fanning reaches out to the injured racer - Sonador (Dreamer in English) - and the pair then have the heart to touch others in such positive ways, including the audience.Fanning is the glue that keeps the family together as she helps her father, Ben Crane, portrayed by Kurt Russell, rehabilitate the racer, who suffered a near fatal injury on the track, and brings the shattered family circle together by reaching out to her grandfather, artfully played by Kris Kristofferson.The opening scene of the filly racer breaking down in the stretch drive is powerful. I saw the film at a sneak preview and the reaction by the audience was if we were witnessing the injury live at the track.Instead of having the runner he was training for a top owner euthanized on the track, Crane purchases the Thoroughbred. The viewer is then led on a journey that culminates with the longshot beating the boys in the Breeders' Cup Classic.There are liberties taken in the story that would certainly infuriate the track curmudgeon. But the Thoroughbred industry stepped up to allow the audience a unique perspective on several aspects of the sport only the most insider views on a daily basis.The story is uplifting and a great family film. And you will cheer each time you watch Sonador win the big race; because of the victory for an underdog in so many ways.

reviewText: I loved this story.  I loved that Dakota Fanning played the girl who ended up owning a broken down horse her father, Kurt Russell, got for her when, instead of shooting the horse after an injury, he took it for his pay.  Kurt Russell played a hardened, down on his luck horse trainer.  Elizabeth Shue is his understanding wife and Kris Kristoffersen is his father.  There were so many suspenseful, idyllic, sad, joyous and wonderfully funny and heartwarming moments in this story. This is the movie where I "found" Freddie Rodriguez. I loved his dream and the way he told it.  His acting has seemed underrated, but I found him mesmerizing. As a personal aside to this movie, after the movie wrapped, Kurt Russell gave Dakota Fanning her own horse...a palomino which she promptly named "Goldie".
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dreamer" is an inspiring movie based about a horse named Sonador who comes back against all odds after nearly being put down by her former owner. This movie is loosely based on a similar story, one involving a horse named Mariah's Storm- a young filly that broke her cannon bone and seemed to be finished with her racing career, only to recover and win several big races.Dreamer is a winning film in several ways. Most important among them are the performances by Kurt Russell and Dakota Fanning. Kurt Russell is a veteran of the big screen and he has appeared in a diverse range of movies. Most movie fans associate Kurt Russell with his tough guy roles, but he proves here that he can easily handle a dramatic role and his performance is excellent. Equally enthralling is the superb performance by eleven year old Dakota Fanning. She is near perfect in her role as the young daughter of Kurt Russell's horse training character. She is intelligent, sensitive, and immensely likeable. You want to see her win, not just at the race track but in life. Kris Kristofferson is also very good in his role as Kurt Russell's father.The other qualities that make Dreamer such a good film are its story of sacrifice and its message of inspiration. Here you have a dad who has already been fired from his job over this young female horse. He then loses possession of the horse but is so inspired by his daughter's story (one that she wrote for a school project and that he reads aloud in front of the class) that he and his father find a way to scrape together the funds to get the horse back. Then, when Sonador is nursed back to health, he gets an offer from his former boss to sell her back to him for a hefty sum of money, not to mention an offer to give him back his job. But Kurt Russell's character has not only his pride at stake, he also has the example and the dreams of his young daughter to consider. He could have easily accepted the offer and rescued himself and his family from a financial crisis. But he turns it down, all for the sake of his beloved little girl.Looking for some missing ingredients in this movie, I can only think of a few. One is the lack of any extensive sports racing footage. When I first heard about this film, I knew it was about horses and I knew it would it would feature some racing scenes. Unfortunately, there are limited races so it will be a disappointment to those who view this movie hoping for some heart- stopping thrills as the racehorses circle the tracks. Another small flaw is the lack of any deep story line. The story is moving and emotional, but it doesn't get very complicated. It is kept at a simplistic level, probably to make it more family friendly.Another thing that bothered me a little with this movie is the lack of screen time for Kurt Russell's wife, played in the movie by Elizabeth Shue. It is easy to see that she and Kurt Russell are close and that they both want the best for their little girl. But Shue has no significant role in the film and her part could have been written out completely without changing the movie in any significant way. Director John Gatins should have found a better way to utilize Elizabeth Shue's many talents and given her a greater role in the film.This movie is generally predictable and you will likely guess the outcome accurately within the first twenty minutes. It also features the typical host of "bad" (Kurt Russell's boss John Palmer) and "good" (Dakota Fanning and Kurt Russell) characters often associated with family films like this. It features a bright, likeable little girl and a hard- working father who wants to do what is right and turns rejects the easy way out in favor of principle."Dreamer" is, overall, a very good movie in spite of its few minor flaws. It's full of clich?'s and it's mostly predictable. But it's still a good movie- entertaining for the entire family and the type of movie that horse lovers will want to watch over and over again. The inspiration of self- sacrifice and the heart warming story make this a movie worth seeing.

reviewText: Ben Crane is a horse trainer who works for money-grubbing, corrupt owners. When the owner's prized philly takes a hard spill during a training run, Ben is advised to put the horse down. Instead, he decides to adopt the horse, and takes her to his farm for rehabilitation. Although Ben comes from a long line of Kentucky horsemen, his farm is rather run-down, and his finances are in dire straits. His wife has to work odd shifts in the town diner, and his relationship with his father and daughter is strained. Soon after adopting the horse and making several unsuccessful attempts to mate her (which can bring in some serious money because of her lineage), he begins training her to race again. To make a long story short, the process of bringing the horse back to the racetrack is what this movie is all about.  ALL of the characters interact well together in this movie. Despite their hardships, they are loyal and committed to each other....wonderful qualities for children to see. I especially loved watching Dakota Fanning on the big screen. Her character is cute, smart, and downright sassy, and her performance is nothing short of phenomenal.Dreamer is a movie that you can watch with your family again and again and love it every time. This is a story about second chances, commitment and courage.Enjoy

reviewText: Dakota Fanning's new horse film, "Dreamer", was not a movie I was planning to see. The trailer was kind of boring and while I enjoy a good horse yarn there's a lot out there right now. But I got free tickets, so I went. And while "Dreamer" doesn't approach such gold standards as "National Velvet" or "The Black Stallion", the film is a well-made and ultimately thrilling story of a horse and its girl.Fanning stars as Cale Crane, the latest in a long line of horse people in the Crane family. The Cranes have fallen on hard times: their horse farm is being sold off piece by piece, Mom has to pick up shifts in a diner, and when one night a horse Mr. Crane is training takes a bad fall Dad loses his job and inherits the busted-up horse to boot.Universally advised to put the horse down, Crane (Kurt Russel) instead plans to fix her up just enough so he can breed her. How that rather reasonable plan evolves into a plan to race the horse, whose name "Sonador" means "dreamer" in Spanish, is the fun of the movie and what makes it a notch above the typical "inspirational" story.The first half of the film drags a bit (shots of clouds going by and grass standing still don't help), but it gets better, and Fanning as usual is great. I thought the young kids in the audience I was with would be bored by the relatively slow tone, but they absolutely loved the movie, and for the entire last five minutes of the film they were cheering and yelling and you couldn't hear what was going on in the film. Based on that reaction I give this film four stars and recommended it to families, especially those with any horse-loving girls. Just explain to your kids that jumping off the house roof onto hay bales is a bad idea, no matter what Fanning does.GRADE: B
summary: "When you ran the earth shook and the sky opened and mere motrals parted..."

reviewText: I love this movie, but then again, after all I had read about it, I thought I would. It didn't disappoint me, except  I didn't play close enough attention to the word "inspired" in the title because, unlike the story of Seabiscuit, this isn't what really happened.It's based on a nice comeback story a real racehorse, "Mariah's Storm," which did make a great comeback from a serious injury but not to the extent of what happens here in this movie. This was exaggerated to the hilt for dramatic purposes, but that's okay once you know that because the story is, indeed, "inspirational."Most important, this is about as nice a modern-day film as you will ever find. There's nary a swear word, hardly even a raised voice. There are nice characters and a sweet, family-friendly tone to it with a tear-in-your-eyes Seabiscuit-type tale and ending.Dakota Fanning once again demonstrates why she is the greatest child actor of her generation. Kurt Russell is excellent, too. Ole Kurt must be mellowing these days playing subdued nice guys like this. It's good to see. The same goes for Elisabeth Shue. This is a far cry from her role in Leaving Las Vegas. Even Kris Kristofferson holds his tongue in this film! Amazing.Like Seabiscuit, this also is beautifully filmed. I wonder if any sport is filmed and is just surrounded by all this beauty in real-life, too, like horse racing? It IS "the sport of kings." There is some spectacular scenery in here, much of it in Kentucky and where better to be when filming a horse racing story?So, if you and your kids - or just you - want to settle in for nice film, and you're looking for a pleasing, nice-looking, feel-good story you absolutely cannot miss with this film. Very highly recommended.
summary: Not Exactly True, But A Wonderful Inspired Story

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: Inspired by a true story, `Dreamer' chronicles a young girl's love for her horse and how that love, and that horse, bring her family closer together.  That young girl is Cale Crane who's played by the very talented Dakota Fanning.  It's truly the strength of the performances that bring this film together, for the general plot of a family falling apart and the love and faith of a child making everything alright has been done plenty of times before, but each actor here brings so much to their roles that they make this a memorable film.  Dakota is such a talented young actress, and while she's not as brilliant as she was in `I am Sam' or even `Man on Fire' she is still ahead of the pack here, and Kurt Russell, while not one of my favorites, is actually very moving as her down and out father Ben.  Elisabeth Shoe, Kris Kristofferson and David Morse co-star in this wonderful family film that is sure to leave the whole family satisfied.

reviewerName: Dan Blankenship "Author of THE RUNNING GIRL"
reviewText: "Dreamer" is a movie the whole family can enjoy.  And yes, it is a little bit corny; but so what?  With so many movies relying on bullets flying, body parts separating, and F-bombs dropping by the plane load, it is always refreshing when a movie like "Dreamer" comes around.  Combine that with three really great actors - Kurt Russell, Dakota Fanning, and Elisabeth Shue - and you have all the makings of a hit movie, I don't really care how well it did or didn't do at the box office.This movie is based on a true story, the dialogue is engrossing, and who doesn't think Dakota Fanning isn't a doll to watch in any movie.  She's like a modern-day Shirley Temple with talent.The original script had a boy playing Cale Crane.  I'm so glad that changed.  Fanning was perfect for this role.The movie addresses a lot of difficult subjects:  racism, class envy, father and son relationships, etc.  And I think that makes the movie a success; these little side-stories fill in the movie quite well.Kris Kristofferson has never been one of my favorite actors, and I can never get past him playing any other role than Abraham Whistler from the "Blade" trilogy.  Naturally I wish another person had played his role in this film - the father of Kurt Russell's character.All and all, I would some up "Dreamer" as an excellent DVD to add to your collection.  It is a movie for all ages.  I can picture me pulling this film out to watch it with my grandchildren one day.  Hopefully, that won't be too soon!So what are you waiting for?  I said it was good!  Click that BUY button.See ya next review.
summary: A Great DVD to Have Available on Your Shelf!

reviewText: "Dreamer-Inspired By a True Story," is one of those rare films that can be enjoyed by both children and adults alike. It's a charming story about overcoming adversity and despair. Instead of looking at unfortunate events as a reason to give up, the characters in this film use these events as the catalyst for realizing their dreams. Dakota Fanning provides the inspiration to keep going, no matter what. In the end, her unwavering positive outlook pays off. Her sheer determination should be a reminder to all that anything is possible when you put your mind to it. "Dreamer," is accompanied by a superb soundtrack and hauntingly beautiful cinematography. Filmed in both Kentucky and Louisiana, the strikingly beautiful scenery adds greatly to an already fine film.
summary: Wonderful film for the entire family!

reviewerName: G. Gupton "Author of spiritual growth books."
reviewText: All-star cast, in my opinion, brings this movie to the top of the ladder for family entertainment. I didn't hear one obsenity in the whole script.The dedication of one little girl to love an animal and to take charge and responsiblity when given the opportunity is priceless. Dakota Fanning's enthusiasm and unfathomable confidence can be a lesson to those watching this remarkable film. There were a few scenes where her eyes gleamed with excitement. There were a few scenes where her smile lit up the screen.Yet, this movie also shows no argument with parents, even though a child may feel disappointment. (What a refreshing message!) She cried, she retreated, she even wanted to run away.For a child to discover what's in their blood and to have parents who recognize their unique love (in this case for a horse) is paramount to emotional health. Sharing popsicles, bonding with a grandparent, given responsibities of ownership, and finally accomplishing a final goal is what this movie is all about.I loved it. I would watch it again. I would recommend it to others. YES. Two thumbs UP.Gail Gupton, author, The 31-Day Diet of Spiritual Enlightenment and Seekers of Truth

reviewText: John Gatins knows his way around uplifting 'family movies' and brings them to a new level with DREAMER.  Though the story's pattern is a well used and familiar one, Gatins has created a strong story and graced it with a fine cast, and though we know from the outset what the ending will be, it is the getting there that is the pleasure of this very watchable film.Ben Crane (Kurt Russell) lives on a once famous Kentucky horse farm, a farm where he and his father Pop Crane (Kris Kristofferson) once bred racehorses.  Now the farm is horseless and Ben simply works as a trainer.  His disappointment in his life situation is reflected in his relative neglect of his wife Lily (Elizabeth Shue), who works as a waitress to make ends meet, and of his daughter Cale (Dakota Fanning).  His life is further encumbered when he advises his boss Palmer (David Morse) that the horse he has trained is not ready for a race and Palmer forces Ben to race the horse only to have the horse Sonador break a leg.  Ben is devastated, Palmer fires Ben and offers Ben severance pay of $6000. plus ownership of Sanador, saving the injured horse from being put down.  This seemingly bottoming out of Ben's career results in his winning his family back: Cale and Ben's faithful workers Balon (Luis Guzman) and ex-jockey badly injured in his past Manolin (Freddy Rodriguez) all work to restore Sanador's health.  Together they nurse Sonya AKA Sanador back to being able to run and reunite the fractured family all in the cause of creating a new life through faith and renewed familial bonding. Sanador is entered in a low level race and while she doesn't win, she demonstrates her viability as a racehorse.  Evil Palmer attempts to buy back the healed Sanador, but Ben has 'sold' the horse to Cale who decides to refuse the buy and proceeds to race Sanador in the Breeder's Cup race - of course winning.What could have been a sugary weeper of a story is brought to a fine level of reality by the fine cast. Fred Murphy is the superb cinematographer, John Debney continues his sterling reputation of composing fine musical scores, and Gatins pulls it all together.  DREAMER may be a family movie, but it is one with enough finesse to please just about every viewer.  Grady Harp, June 06

reviewText: Dreamer was inspired by the true story of Mariah's Storm, a racehorse who suffered thru the same severe injury as Sonador and, astonishingly, went on to win more horse races. Screenwriter/Director John Gatins had originally intended a boy to play Dakota Fanning's role, until he went and saw Man on Fire and knew he had to get Dakota for his movie. How's that for a testimony on your acting skills? And she's only 10 years old! Dreamer - Inspired By a True Story is excellent, heartwarming family fare. If the film makers crafted this film with the intention of creating a classic, they succeeded.The story tells of the estranged Crane family, who has been going thru the motions as a family. Ben Crane (Kurt Russell), the father, is too consumed with his work as a second hand horse trainer to spend much time with his neglected wife Lily (Elisabeth Shue - Rrrrrrr!) and their precocious daughter Cale (Dakota Fanning). Ben has also been on the outs with his own dad "Pop" (the ever grizzled Kris Kristofferson). Director John Gatins introduces a chestnut thoroughbred filly named Sonador and uses her as the means of bridging all the rifts in their relationships. Sonador's nickname is Sonia, though, in Spanish, Sonador translates to Dreamer.Ben Crane had just gotten fired due to his succoring an injured filly, who had suffered a devastating leg injury whilst on her way to winning a race. With no job and with expenses continuing to mount, events seem to spiral downhill for the Cranes. Even the hope that Sonador will make money thru breeding is dashed when she is proclaimed infertile. Ben is just about at his wits' end when, ultimately, it is young Cale herself who accidentally starts to turn things around for the Cranes, for the better. The remainder of the film divulges the twists and turns this horse-training family undergoes, as the storyline builds to a crescendo with the unlikely entry of Sonador into the prestigious Breeders' Cup Classic.There are obvious echoes of the awesome Seabiscuit film in Dreamer. Dreamer, too, is about an injured underdog racehorse who goes on to beat the odds. Like Seabiscuit, Dreamer also is about the coming together of people who were fractured. As Sonador is rehabilitated, so, too, is the alienated Crane family healed. Another tie which Dreamer has with Seabiscuit is that horse wranglers  Rusty Hendrickson and Rex Peterson worked the horse sequences on both films. In terms of texture and resonance, another film that this one reminds me of is National Velvet. Young Elizabeth Taylor and Dakota Fanning seem to be cut from the same talented mold.This movie is all about hope. And hope is personified, above all others, in Cale Crane, as enchantingly played by Fanning. The secret's been out for some time now that Dakota Fanning can act well - and not just well for a youngster. It's weird to say this about someone so young, but Fanning has such an open, organic style to her acting. I truly anticipate more good things from her. While the entire cast is across the board excellent, it is Fanning and Russell - a child actor and a former child actor - who anchor the film. These two seemed to share a father-daughter chemistry which made them a delight to watch in their scenes together. Kurt Russell puts in a low keyed, nuanced performance as a disillusioned horse trainer who, because of Cale and her filly, finds the courage to hope and dream big again.The Special Features include the featurettes "Who is Mariah's Storm?" (about the racehorse who inspired Dreamer), "On the Set - Working with Thoroughbreds" & "Taking Care of Horses" (both segments are about what it's like working with the horses), "Meet the Dreamer Dream Cast" (focus on the film cast), 2 deleted scenes, film commentary by Director/Writer John Gatins, a 9-minute long segment from the live sports show "Trackside Live" with guest John Gatins, and the music video "Dreamer" by Bethany Dillon.Dreamer works as a layered generational story, a root-for-the-underdog tale, and as a sensitive family drama. It is sentimental, syrupy sweet, and it deliberately works to tug at your heartstrings (wait 'til you hear the classroom story Cale wrote). And, yes, it's even, at times, cliched. But, to me, it's a perfect movie. A classic, in fact.
summary: "She wasn't just some racehorse. She was our horse."

reviewText: Dakota Fanning, Elizabeth Shue, Kurt Russell, Kris Kristofferson (sorry I can't spell this name), make a wonderful ensemble and are nicely complemented by the supporting actors.What is most striking about the film are the qualities of simplicity and beauty.  None of the actors appear to overshadow another.  They speak quietly, move quietly and really seem to live in their surroundings.  Dakota as Cale Crane is very convincing as the lone child of a horseman without a horse and a mom who's making ends meet by working at the local diner.  There is no Hollywood glamour thrown in to make the actors shine.  Dakota Fanning impressed me in this movie particularly because she really seemed like a young girl with a dream - to follow in her father's and grandfather's footsteps and make something of the broken horse called Sonador (Dreamcatcher).
summary: A dreamer with its feet firmly on the ground!

reviewText: This was basically the first horse movie I had ever seen and liked. I didn't like the movie version of "Seabiscuit" or the various other horse films made throughout the years. This wasn't the top on my list of must-see movies, but I went anyway.First off, the trailers (particularly the super-long one shown on evening tv) did this film a major dis-service. The trailers show Dakota Fanning and Kurt Russell in cheesy, lame moments, so I was expecting this of the movie. Not so. The story of a good horse who is injured, then fixed, then injured again, then fixed for good was terrific. In parts in was hilarious, and the supporting cast fit in perfectly with the two main stars (I especially liked Kris Kristofferson as "Pop"). For the most part, you know what's going to happen, but it doesn't matter. It's fun to watch them struggle and learn, and at times it is very..touching.And about the cheesy moments..they're not cheesy in the context of the film. It is very enjoyable from start to finish, and the dialogue, for the most part, is believable. I would recommend this one for anybody, unless you don't like horses. Well, that's it for me. Farewell, and happy trails...

reviewText: This is a great family movie.  Dakota is demanding her father's attention and wants more and more of his time.  She has the love of horses in her blood and no one is going to stand in her way.  This is a story about a race horse that gets hurt during a race and Dakota's father won't let them put him down.  They take many chances on this horse and those chances pay off, but it has been a rough journey. Dakota delivers a great performance as well as Kurt Russell who plays her father and Kris Kristofferson who plays her Grandfather.  Anyone, any age, any sex, will enjoy this movie.  Also, this is based on a true story.

reviewText: Bracketed by a very strong cast, this predictable Hollywood family film is vastly entertaining. Great acting by Kurt Russell and some great supporting actors make create a storyline that speaks to redemption and second chances for horses and people alike. Adults will find the parental drama compelling, and of course, the kids will groove over the in depth accuracy of horse farming. Facinating tidbits of info about racing, medical technology, the business of horsing. Dakota Fanning, as usual, is natural in her role.

reviewText: Kurt Russell is a man whose horse farm has no horses.  He works for another man's stable and has strained relationships with his father and his daughter.  When he advises his boss not to run a horse, the man ignores him and runs her anyway.  Predictably the horse pulls up lame and Russell is told to euthanize him.  Instead, he decides to buy the horse and rehabilitate her, and in the process his family relationships begin to mend.  Russell is a natural as a distant father who learns to become close to his daughter.  Dakota Fanning is old and wise beyond her years and is perfectly cast as the spunky Cale Crane who believes that her horse can become a winner.  The ending is a foregone conclusion, but getting there is pure pleasure for adults and children alike.

reviewText: When I asked my son why he liked this movie so much, he simply said that it was very exciting (he didn't add that it also moved him deeply, a fact I know because I saw him trying to hide his tears at one point).As many viewers may know by now, Dakota Fanning is one major talent, a child actress who seems both believable and unique, a special soul who is so intensely involved in her performances that it is nearly impossible not to get caught up in her spell.In this film, she plays the daughter of a man who is down on his luck, unable to catch a break. Somehow she manages to convince him that one horse is worth saving and then, possibly, able to race again.Gotta give credit to Dakota Fanning and Kurt Russell for keeping this one believable and not letting it sink into the realm of sentimental pap. But it does not, resulting in a magical film which is also inspiring.Try to catch this one on the big screen, as the racing scenes are much more intense that way. It'll still be good on DVD but I think this is one film which deserves to be seen in theatres.

reviewText: This is a very good fact based drama.  The story is solid, but what makes this film outstanding is the cast chosen, and not enough good things can be said about them.  Kurt Russell is a horse trainer from Kentucky.  His look and mannerisms are spot on, and he carries this role well.  Dakota Fanning is the daughter and the heart of the movie with Elizabeth Shue cast as mom.  Kris Kristoferson is the father/grandfather, and no one could have played this role.  His gruff unbending exterior is flawless.

reviewText: Well, here's a big surprise--"Dreamer" holds no surprises. It's an oft told tale--girl finds horse, girl loses horse, girl gets horse back, and together they can be legends! The horse in question here is a racing champion who breaks a leg. Instead of putting it down, the girl and her father save and mend it. When that goes exceedingly well, all hopes return to making a racing champion once again.The girl in question is Dakota Fanning. Gosh, who's going to root against her? While this is not my favorite Fanning performance, I am awed by her talent in general. I still think it's criminal that she was overlooked for an Emmy nomination for "Taken" and an Oscar nomination for the horrendous "I Am Sam" (a film she all but holds together due to a ridiculously over-the-top performance by the nominated Sean Penn).Kurt Russell is her dour father learning to believe again. He's fine. But in two underwritten roles, I did like what Elisabeth Shue and Kris Kristofferson have to contribute. They bring some of the less obvious moments of pleasure to the film.Not content to just play the underdog story of the horse, the film also throws in a damaged jockey that needs to be rehabilitated. For even more dramatic effect, in the title race he almost falls off the horse. Now, I'm not going to spoil any surprises--so you'll just have to watch the film to see how this unlikely duo will fare (but let's just say they start out in a distant last place). But that's not all--"Dreamer" offers more than just these two underdog stories--oh, yes! This piece has a true villain, as well. In easily the film's (and perhaps last year's) most thankless performance is the talented David Morse. He disregards the safety of the horses, humiliates and fires Russell, displays racist condescension and publicly mocks a little girl. He glowers at everything and resorts to sabotage, when in truth--I don't think he'd be threatened by our heroic team. And Morse all but twirls his mustache and cackles maniacally in a totally unnecessary and unrealistic portrait.No matter how you slice it up--people are going to love this story as much as every other similar story that came before. To not is to be a cold hearted jerk. I didn't buy into everything wholeheartedly, but it's decent family fare. It's cozy, safe, predictable and uplifting--non-challenging cinema at it's best. KGHarris, 10/06.
summary: A Girl, A Horse, And A Recurring Dream--Yet Another Underdog Story
Title: N/A

reviewText: If a thoroughbred horse isn't making money some tough business decisions must be made. However, a child's dreams can be counterintuitive to sound business decisions. DREAMER portrays a precocious child, Cale (Dakota Fanning), that overcomes seemingly insurmountable odds to achieve multiple triumphs. Her father, Ben Crane (Kurt Russell), initially views Cale as an impediment to his work. After Ben does everything he can to salvage a lame horse's value, he realizes that the best person to decide the animal's fate is his young daughter.The overall plot is somewhat far fetched though based on a true story (about a different horse with a varied outcome). The language is clean for the most part (one use of h*ll) and there is no violence (besides falling off a horse), making this appropriate entertainment for an entire family. The DVD contains many interesting extras -- background on how various scenes were filmed, interviews with the actors, a story about the horse upon which the movie is loosely based, and guidance for properly grooming a horse.Movie quote: "You are a great champion. When you ran the ground shook. The sky opened and mere mortals parted."
summary: The only thing lame about this movie is the horse (recommended)
Title: N/A

reviewText: The horse race at the end of "Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story" is something of an anticlimax, because I discovered that at least from my view in the grandstand this was not a movie about a girl and her horse.  That of course, is how "Dreamer" was sold, and when you have Dakota Fanning in a film you know that she is going to steal scenes right and left, especially if she is working with a horse.  In fact, when Kurt Russell's name popped up first in the credits my immediate thought was that they should just put Fanning first because she is the star.  But the big emotional moments in this film do not come from Fanning; they come from Russell.Ben Crane (Russell) is a horse trainer working for a rich jerk named Palmer (David Morse).  They are working with a two-year-old filly named So'ador (Spanish for "dreamy" apparently), and Ben does not think the horse should run.  Palmer is working with Saudi princes so he forces the issue and the horse breaks a leg.  The track vet wants to put the horse down, but when Ben looks up his daughter Cale (Fanning) is there, her eyes wide, and he cannot do it.  What happens costs him his job, but as part of his impromptu severance package he gets the damaged horse.Now, the main plotline of the film is that Cale wants to take care of So'ador and believes that the horse will be able to run again.  Part of this is wishful thinking by a little girl, but Cale is third generation when it comes to working with horses and playing wise beyond her years is a piece of cake for Fanning.  But what happens with the horse is pretty much predictable from start to finish line, and what I found compelling was the story of fathers and their kids.  Pop Crane (Kris Kristofferson) is still around, and while he thinks Ben's decision not to put down the injured horse was a mistake, the fact his son actually took a stand starts to thaw their relationship.  At the same time, Ben and Kale are moving towards having a stronger relationship, which only starts to happen when she becomes the owner of the horse and hires him to be the trainer.It is good to see Fanning doing her required horse film and "Dreamer" is just another example of why she is the most sought after pre-teen actress since Shirley Temple (she has already bested every other contender in between).  Put Fanning in a room with adults and she more than holds her own.  But watch dreamer and the two best moments both involve Russell.  The first is when he goes to Parents Night at Cale's school and the teacher has him stand up and read the story his daughter has written.  It is a story about a king in a castle who needs a magic horse to restore his kingdom, and as Ben reads it the metaphors fade away and he realizes what Cale is saying to him (the camera moves in slowly on Russell as he reads).  "Can we keep these?" he asks the teacher when he is finished, and you just know this guy is going to be buried with that story in his casket.The second memorable moment comes during the race, when the horses are galloping around the track, and Ben turns to look at his daughter watching the race.  At that point the horse does not matter and neither does the race, because Ben has everything he wants in watching his daughter.  Actually, that is not quite true, because the point at which Ben has everything is when he feels his father's hand on his shoulder.  His attention will be drawn back to the race, but this movie has found its happy ending well before it fades to black.The "Inspired by a True Story" part of the title really does not matter than much.  Writer-director John Gatins had come up with a story about a race horse that comes back from a potentially crippling injury and when he shared it with those in horse racing they all mentioned the real story of Mariah's Storm, who came back from a back injury to win a bunch of races (but not the Breeder's Cup).  So what is "true" here is that a horse can come back from a broken shinbone.  Of course, post "Seabiscuit" America's movie goers should have no problem accepting this tale.
summary: In this horse race, it turns out to be Kurt Russell's movie more than Dakota Fanning's

reviewText: The director was approached by Hollyweird insiders, saying he needs to add language, and more adult situations to make it a success! He disagreed, and thankfully so! The movie was very inspirational, and uplifting, and had excellent family values in it.Kurt Russell plays a father, a son, and a husband who is suffering through poverty... he is rekindling his relationship with Dakota Fanning as his daughter who instantly makes the audience's heart melt with her smiles and personality. reviewText: DREAMER is one of those wonderful, feel-good movies, all too rare in today's Hollywood of sex, drugs and violence. The based-on-a-true story of a trainer (Kurt Russell), who buys a horse with a broken leg and brings it back to racing condition, is well-acted all around and has a tight script. The trainer's daughter (Dakota Fanning) befriends the horse and becomes involved in its recovery and ultimate entry into a Breeder's Cup race. Dakota Fanning is amazing in this role as both a sweet and tough-minded child. She demostrates the acting ability of someone twice her age. DREAMER is a fine show for the whole family, entertaining while giving inspiration and painlessly teaching positive values in the process. A must see.
summary: DAKOTA SHINES IN GREAT FAMILY FILM

reviewText: "Dreamer" is a sort of "National Velvet" for a new generation, a story about a girl and the horse she loves, starring the biggest child star of her generation, Dakota Fanning -as the 1944 film starred Elizabeth Taylor. Billed as a "family film", "Dreamer" does have some of that corniness that I've come to associate with films that are ostensibly made for children, but it is elevated by a superb cast who make the film enjoyable for adults as well. When horse trainer Ben Crane (Kurt Russell) is fired by his arrogant boss Everett Palmer (David Morse), Ben takes an injured horse, Sonador, as part of his severance pay, with the intention of breeding Sonador with a champion for profit. Ben and his two assistants, Balon (Luis Guzman) and ex-jockey Manolin (Freddie Rodriguez), set about getting the horse's leg to heal so that she can breed, while the Crane family hopes their precarious finances will hold out that long. In the meanwhile, Ben's daughter Cale (Dakota Fanning) has fallen in love with Sonador, and when things don't go as planned, Cale's lofty ambitions to race the horse in the Breeders' Cup Classic might be the silver lining in the Crane's dark cloud."Dreamer" is plagued by clichés and details that don't make sense, but it is all forgivable thanks to a very credible cast and racing scenes that succeed in getting the audience on the edge of its seat better than any other horse-racing film I have seen. Dakota Fanning provides the star power and energy that drives the story, while Kurt Russell grounds the film in reality with skepticism and reticence. This is writer/director John Gatins first stab at directing, and, although his script may be faulted for being too saccharine in places, his directing is most effective. It helps that Gatins knows horses and horse-racing well, so he's comfortable with the material. "Inspired by a True Story" was tacked onto the film's title out of necessity, since another studio owned the title "Dreamer". This film is entirely fiction. But there was a horse named "Mariah's Storm" who recovered from a broken leg to have a successful racing career, so she is the "true story" to which the title refers. "Dreamer" is obviously a contrived feel-good, and sometimes feel-bad, story that never pretends to be otherwise. But it has the emotional authenticity and excitement that make such a story enjoyable -for young and old.The DVD (Dreamworks 2006): Bonus features include 5 featurettes, 2 deleted scenes, a "Music Video Featuring Bethany Dillon" (3 min), and an audio commentary by director John Gatins. "Who Is Mariah's Storm?" (5 min) is a bio of the horse referred to in the film as having had the same injury as Sonador. "On the Set: Working with Thoroughbreds" (11 min) includes interviews with horse wranglers Rusty Hendrickson and Rex Peterson, discussion of the horses that played Sonador, and filming the race scenes. "Taking Care of Horses" (5  min) shows the daily routine of grooming a horse, for young girls. "Meet the Dreamer Dream Cast" (17 min) includes interviews with the cast, director John Gatins, and director of photography Fred Murphy, in which they talk about characters, story, and working with each other. "Trackside Live Dreamer Segment" (9 min) is a television broadcast from Oaktree Santa Anita, in which a sportscaster interviews John Gatins trackside about the upcoming film. John Gatins' feature audio commentary includes a lot of technical details of how scenes were created and filmed, as well as scene-by-scene comments on locations, characters, and story. It's an informative commentary without lulls. Subtitles are available for the film in English, Spanish, French. Dubbing is available in French.
summary: Contrived but Ultimately Engaging Story of a Girl and Her Horse.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Anyone out there who is a sucker for a sweet, simple movie need not look any further than Dakota Fanning's most recent film, "Dreamer." As other reviewers here have said, the story is genuinely heartfelt, the scenery is beautiful and the general tone is ideal for a movie to enjoy with the family.As we all know, 11-year-old Dakota Fanning has fashioned an impressively long string of films since she first broke out with "I Am Sam" at age 6, and after starring in three horror/action flicks in a row (Man On Fire, Hide and Seek, and War of the Worlds), it was nice to see her return to the family genre for younger crowds. She did an incredible job here, of course, and worked very well alongside Kurt Russell.One thing that really did surprise me, though, was how low-key Dakota's performance was with this film. She couldn't have spoken more than about ten words in the film's first thirty minutes, and throughout the rest of the movie she seemed to be speaking more through those big blue eyes of hers, rather than verbal dialogue. After getting quite a bit of heat in "War of the Worlds" this past summer for shrieking and crying throughout the movie's duration (her past few movie scripts, for that matter, have called for quite a bit of screaming), you may be surprised to see how soft and delicate her dialogue is in "Dreamer." Her role as a sweet, mild-tempered, and shy young girl is one that actually has her speaking much less than she does in her other movies, but her quiet and innocent presence works perfectly with her character. After having to put forth so much emotion and wear a scared face in her previous roles, she gets an opportunity to play a much quieter part and pulls it off beautifully, reaffirming her incredible diversity as an actress.I would highly recommend this film to all Dakota fans, as well as those who would be happy with a movie that literally makes you smile. That's the kind of plot that is used from the very beginning, leading up to a fantastic ending that is cliche, yes, but very much the kind of satisfying conclusion we all love.
summary: another terrific success for Ms. Fanning
Title: N/A

reviewText: The movie focuses on Cale (Fanning) and her family who happen to be in the horse racing business in Kentucky. She happens to interfere after one of the horses, Sonador (aka "Dreamer"),  managed by her father (Russell) gets injured in a race and so saves the horse from death.  Thus begins a healing process as much for the horse as for the family.Now this being a family movie and being based on a true story, the ending is as predictable as the rising of the sun each morning, but that doesn't really matter.  The movie is absolutely fantastic: it's sweet and charming, and the cast is amazing, notably Kurt Russell, but especially Dakota Fanning who steals the show.  And just as an added bonus, the landscape is also very beautiful to look at!The movie reminded me a lot of the movie "Seabiscuit", because at its core it's basically the same story - horse gets hurt and there's a healing process that affects everyone - and it has basically the same ending. But "Dreamer" is like the kid version. It's not as serious or long, it's fun for the whole family, and it's just as good.  It's a movie I'd definitely recommend (and in the same vein if you enjoyed this, go for "Seabiscuit" for the adults)!

reviewText: It's hard not to get excited about a movie that shows horse racing but this movie has so much more than just the horse racing.  I'm always on the lookout for good family movies that I can watch with my granddaughter and great nieces and nephews...movies that display the values I feel are important in my family's lives and show, in action and words, a way of life the children in my life to pattern their lives.  This movie fits the bill!I watched the movie with a 13, 10, 5, 64 and 65 year old...and it was enjoyed by all.  The kids were entranced with the horse and racing, of course, but also loved the way the Dad and little girl's relationship improved.  They loved watching the little girl take the lead in working hard to make a dream come true and understood how this helped heal the relationship between the father and grandfather as well.It taught us "older" children to remember our dreams and still fight for them and to remember to instill dreams in our children and help them grow into working for those dreams and following them.As in life, there are some harsh scenes that made the young ones cry and ask, "is she going to die"...scary, sad scenes about scary, sad things that happen, so parents and grandparents, be prepared to help.I would definitely buy this product again and recommend it for others.  The casting was great.  Dakota Fanning had good "attitude" and Kurt Russell and father, Kris Kristofferson looked and acted like they were father/son in real life.  The fact that this story was inspired by a true story makes it even better.Definitely a movie for my library!

reviewText: I was lucky enough to see an advanced screening of this film in LA a couple of weeks ago, and can best describe it as a "feel good" movie. There were no real surprises as far as the main plot points were concerned, however, this is not really a criticism with this particular film, as what makes it work are the uniformly good to excellent performances of all the main characters.As an aside, the films subtitle, "Inspired by a True Story," is correct; the horses name was "Mariah's Storm," and she won the 1995 Breeders' Cup after breaking her leg, an event that usually results in the poor animal being put-down on the track.Dakota Fanning is scarily good as always, Kurt Russell puts in a solid, believable performance as her dad, and an impossibly grizzled Kris Kristofferson ambles and growls his way through the movie as her grandfather. A pleasant surprise was David Morse, probably best known to most of us as TV's "Hack," in a decidedly unsympathetic role, one which he pulls off with great aplomb.I only have a couple of major criticisms, there's a pivotal plot point concerning what appears to be the forced sale of Dreamer, called a "claim," after a race, midway through the film, which left me, my girlfriend, and I'm sure most of the rest of the audience not intimately involved in the racing world, completely bemused, as the process is never explained. Secondly, the family farm is, apparently, the only horse farm in Kentucky with no horses; this is obviously tied to something really BAD that happened to Kristofferson's character many years ago, but again, is left unexplained.The good points are, as I said, the performances of Fanning, Russell, Kristofferson, and Morse; these really carry the film along and go an awful long way to letting you forgive the formulaic plotting. Another plus is the filming of the race sequences themselves; the camera seems to get right in amongst the horses as they thunder around the track, and there're a couple of tight overhead shots that really give you a feel for the speed and closeness of the action taking place.All in all this is a very pleasant way to spend 100 minutes or so; go for the performances - Fanning blows everyone off the screen AGAIN! - and the race sequences, and you won't be disappointed. The film is decidedly family-friendly, although the sequence where Dreamer breaks a leg at the beginning MAY be upsetting for some children.

reviewText: Although the story is fictional, Dreamer is loosely based upon but completely inspired by the injury, recovery, and racing career of a real horse, Mariah's Storm.  Although the real horse did not fare as well as the fictional Sonador, the movie is a heartwarmer.  Well cast by actors who know how to follow direction to strengthen and support each other, not steal scenes, each role feels quietly familiar.  We all deal with childlike dreams, adult doubts, unfair challenges, and blindsided setbacks.  Each challenge finds a home in Dreamer, but the truly inspirational part of the movie is an emotionally absent parent, his choice to change, the unconditional love of his young daughter, and the scripted focus of an inspired filly.  Sure it is a movie and pure fantasy, but it is a good one.  Don't be surprised if you find yourself laughing, crying, smiling, and cheering in the privacy of your own home.  I know I did.The DVD transfer is exceptional with crisp colors and sharp closeups, nearing Blu-ray perfection.  The Dolby 5.1 sound is outstanding.  Dreamer is a great way to invest both a few dollars and a couple hours of your life, especially with family you love.
summary: Absolutely heartwarming and inspirational way to invest 106 minutes of your life

reviewText: . . . and enjoy the ride. Unexpected twists in the plot outline and remarkably good child acting lend a ray of freshness and suprise to a story of a girl and her horse. If you like Black Beauty, The Black Stallion, National Velvet, and other favorite horse movies, you are bound to like this one, too. There is some language I disaprove of, which is why I knocked off one star. There are parents who would not like their children to hear "d***" and "h***", so, buyers, be aware. For the most part it's an all around enjoyable and original story that can be appreciated. As I said before, it has great child acting -- something hard to come by these days. Cale is potrayed as an intelligent, sensetive, and creative little girl with a big heart. She doesn't have a rotten attitude or an aray of bad habits. Beautiful filming and music. Something I'd watch again.

reviewText: Kurt Russell, 1ce 1 of Disney's dream kids, returns to his roots in this lovely horsey story.  Set in the Real World rather than Disney's Perfect Place, -Dreamer- follows a girl, Cale [Dakota Fanning, in yet another star turn] torn between her hard-working dad  Ben [Russell] & harder grandfather Pop [Kris Kristofferson, looking as tho he'd been rode hard & put away wet], w/her pretty waitress mom [Elizabeth Shue] set inbetween.The story's pretty pedestrian: When Ben is proven right ["That horse don't wanna race today."] & a racing filly breaks her leg, he takes the horse & plans to breed her.  Foiled by her lack of fertility, Ben is surprised when she turns out to have fully healed.  Fate conspires to put the filly's life in Cale's hands, where the rivalry between 2 Arab brothers & the bullying of a nasty owner [David Morse, doing all but whirling non-existant mustachios] lead to sweet justification.Hey, it's a horse film; you expect anything else?!!  But it has a misty, fairy tale feel, nicely contrasted by the gritty realism of the setting.  & in the end the king is served coffee & pie by his friends....

reviewText: This was a really good movie. My whole family enjoyed watching it. Every body loves an underdog, and this is an underdog story. Ben Crane is a disillusioned man who has lost his vision, his hope, and his meaning. He gets scapegoated for a terrible injury to the champion horse Sonador. Ironically, had he been listened to in the first place the accident would never have happened. He is fired and blacklisted, therefore unable to find work. He winds up keeping the horse, and does the impossible nursing her back to health. There were many moving themes in this film. Especially the importance of reconciling differences within a family in spite of deep hurt; as well as the importance of spending time together.  The performances of the stars were outstanding, and the finale was inspiring. While somewhat predictable, the movie works very well, and left me feeling good after watching it.

reviewText: A word of warning from a wannabe-parent:  this movie isn't designed with children in mind.  I like Dakota Fanning and think she is a very talented young actress.  But I don't know why her parents and/or agent signed her on for this movie.  The idea is that after a bad accident on the track, a horse named Sonjador is bought and cared for by Kurt Russell and his family (his daughter is Dakota Fanning).  They nurse the horse back to health with the intent of racing her again.  I have no problem with that portion of the movie.  It's the earlier part when they intend to breed the horse in order to hopefully spawn a young champion to sell.  Too much blatant sexual discussion of intercourse between the stud and Sonjador, right in front of Dakota Fanning who's character must be having a tough time figuring out what they're talking about.  Plus I detected an almost subliminal theme of lechery running throughout the movie as many older male characters make very thinly veiled advances towards young Fanning (even by her grandfather, played by the otherwise reliable Kris Krisstofferson).  Basically I believe the movie is well-made enough for adults (and probably older teens), but like Disney's animated "Hunchback of Notre Dame" this movie is too much for the kids.

reviewText: Ben Crane was once a great horseman, whose gifts as a trainer, were wasted on making other men's fortunes. Sonya was once a great horse, whose promising career on the racetrack was cut short, suddenly, by a broken leg. Considered as good as dead to her owner--who also happens to be Ben's boss--Sonya is given to Ben as his severance pay, along with his walking papers. Now, it will take the unwavering faith and determination of Ben's young daughter, Cale, to bring these two damaged souls together in a quest for a seemingly impossible goal: to win the Breeders' Cup Classic. However, the true miracle might be that, in helping this injured horse, what they are actually healing is their own family. This movie is good family entertainment. Dakota Fanning and Kurt Russell give a remarkable performance takes this family move to a whole other level and more.
summary: Dreamer - Inspired By a True Story

reviewText: "Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story" might easily remind you of another based-on-real-life-event film about horse race, "Seabiscuit." The biggest difference is that "Dreamer" helmed by the first-time director John Gatins (who wrote the script of Keanu Reeves' "Hard Ball") takes a more straightforward approach to the underdog theme. The result is a family picture that, though formulaic and predictable, is still engaging and heart-warming with the superb acting from the cast. And the titular horse is also good.The story is loosely based on a real-life racing horse named "Mariah's Storm," who broke her cannon bone in 1993, but kept winning the races after miraculously coming back from the near fatal injury. The film changed the horse's name to more romantic "Sonador" (meaning Dreamer), and changed many other things too, but the results remain a very moving film with effective acting all around.Dakota Fanning, busiest actresses in the world (child or adult), plays Cale Crane, daughter of the horse trainer Ben Crane (Kurt Russell). After the terrible accident that happened to Sonador, a promising race horse, they save the life of the severely injured mare, and bring her to their house, where the daughter starts to take care of her.There is a greedy horse owner (David Morse); one jockey who once gave up his dream (Freddy Rodriguez); quiet and gritty grandfather `Pop' Crane (Kris Kristofferson), and patient and understanding Lily (Elizabeth Shue). Plus you can see Luis Guzmán and Oded Fehr, and their roles are not surprising ones. Actually, everyone in the film is typecast, but the unanimously good acting from the cast makes us almost forget the fact. Just almost.The strength of the film, besides the fine performances from the actors, is the credible and thrilling race scenes. The graceful beauty of the horse is also attractive.But above all, we are attracted to the "True Story" simply because it tells a good story with skills and confidence. The actors also know that they are part of that good story, and look proud of that. True, it is a bit too good, but is also a very moving one.
summary: Sonador, the Dreamer: Inspirational Family Picture

reviewText: I think decent folks between the ages of eight and 108 would all enjoy this horse and little-girl in the big race tale. There are moral lessons about fathers and sons, husbands and wives, good and evil  business decisions as well. Overall, it might be called predictable, but much of the best stuff in it is pretty subtle. I just plain loved it. The cast is perfect, the cinematography pleasing, the script effective. And the horse is adorable. April, 2011 update: Just saw it for a second time, this time via DVD. One mark of an effective film is whether or not, when you see it again, it can have the same emotional wallop. For me, the second time around with "Dreamer" the emotions are even larger. In the time since my first review, I have attended a lot more horse races, and acquired several more blonde female grandchildren who look and sound like Dakota does in the movie. Hard to keep back the tears when watching this one...some due to sad moments, some to deeply touching scenes. And I still wanted to stand up and cheer during the big race.
summary: For anyone with a heart and a conscience, it's great...
